Checking In Files

Starting with StarTeam 2005, when you check in a file from a working folder on your computer, the application stores it by the MD5 value of its contents. If the file is identified as one that compresses well, it is compressed and placed in the hive's archive with a .gz extension. Otherwise, the uncompressed version is placed in the hive's archive.

To check in files:

  1. Select a folder from the folder hierarchy.

  2. Select the File tab, then highlight one or more files on the File list. Make the necessary revisions.

  3. Select Check In from the File or context menu. The Check In dialog opens.

  4. Do one of the following:

    • Enter a generic reason for the check-in in the Comment text box.

    • Select the Prompt for a comment (check-in reason) for each file check box. This action open a separate dialog for each file in which you can enter a comment.

  5. (Optional) To compare the files you are checking in to the tip revision of the files in the repository, click the Compare button. If differences exist, this action launches Visual Diff, which shows file changes.

  6. Select the Lock status option:

    • Unlocked, to release your lock on the files after check-in.

    • Exclusive, to indicate that you intend to make further changes to the files.

    • Non-exclusive, to indicate that you are working on the files and may possibly make changes.

    • Keep current, to retain the current lock status.

  7. (Optional) Select Force check-in to check in files that are older than the tip revision.

  8. If desired, select the Delete working files check box to delete the files from the working folder on your workstation, storing them only in the application. Clear this check box to retain these files in the working folder, as well as storing them in the application.

  9. (Required if process items are enforced) To link file revisions to a process item, select the Link and pin process item check box. If the use of process items is required, this check box is selected by default. See Understanding Process Rules and Linking File Revisions to Process Items.

  10. If work on the active process item is now complete, select the Mark selected process item as fixed/finished/complete check box.

  11. (Optional) Select a label from the Revision label drop-down combo box or create a new revision label by entering its name. Existing labels are listed in reverse chronological order, based on the time at which they were created.

    12. Remember that the same label cannot be used for two revisions of the same file. Therefore, if the label you want to use is currently associated with a previous revision, you must also select the Move the label if it's already assigned to a previous revision check box.

  12. If you are using the Windows client:

    1. If desired, click Show Change Requests to review the change requests linked to the files you are checking in.

    2. Click OK to check in the files

  13. If you are using the Cross-Platform client, you have additional options that may be useful. To access these options:

    1. Click Advanced. This action displays the Advanced Options dialog.

    2. (Optional)  Select the Perform EOL conversion (CR-LF) check box to control the EOL character that is stored with the files. The default setting for this check box is based on the EOL setting in your Personal Options.

    3. In the drop down list box, select the appropriate File encoding.

    4. If desired, click Show Change Requests to review the change requests linked to the files you are checking in.

    5. Click OK to return to the Check In dialog.

    6. Click OK to check in the files.

Note: Click the Check In icon or the Check In And Unlock on the toolbar to check in files without using the Check In dialog. If process rules are required, the dialog will open anyway.
